title: Permanent crop
text:
A permanent crop is one produced from <a href="plant">plant</a>s which last for many <a href="season">season</a>s, rather than being replanted after each <a href="harvest">harvest</a>.
Traditionally, "<a href="arable%20land">arable land</a>" included any land suitable for the growing of crops, even if it was actually being used for the production of permanent crops such as <a href="vineyard">grapes</a> or <a href="orchard">peaches</a>. Modern <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a>particularly organizations such as the <a href="Central%20Intelligence%20Agency">CIA</a> and <a href="Food%20and%20Agriculture%20Organization">FAO</a>prefer the <a href="term%20of%20art">term of art</a> to describe such <a href="cultivable%20land">cultivable land</a> that is not being used for annually-harvested crops such as <a href="staple%20grain">staple grain</a>s. In such usage, permanent cropland is a form of agricultural land that includes <a href="grassland">grassland</a>s and <a href="shrubland">shrubland</a>s used to grow grape vines or <a href="coffee%20plantation">coffee</a>; <a href="orchard">orchard</a>s used to grow <a href="fruit%20orchard">fruit</a> or <a href="olive">olive</a>s; and forested <a href="plantation">plantation</a>s used to grow <a href="nut%20plantation">nuts</a> or <a href="rubber%20plantation">rubber</a>. It does not include, however, <a href="tree%20farm">tree farm</a>s intended to be used for <a href="wood">wood</a> or <a href="timber">timber</a>.
